bug.author: LINYOUWEI0804
bug.description:
This program is an example of tensorflow integer quantizationï¼š def representative_data_gen(): for input_value in tf.data.Dataset.from_tensor_slices(train_images).batch(1).take(100): yield [input_value] converter = tf.lite.TFLiteConverter.from_keras_model(model) converter.optimizations = [tf.lite.Optimize.DEFAULT] converter.representative_dataset = representative_data_gen <denchmark-h:h1>Ensure that if any ops can't be quantized, the converter throws an error</denchmark-h>
converter.target_spec.supported_ops = [tf.lite.OpsSet.TFLITE_BUILTINS_INT8] <denchmark-h:h1>Set the input and output tensors to uint8 (APIs added in r2.3)</denchmark-h>
converter.inference_input_type = tf.uint8 converter.inference_output_type = tf.uint8 tflite_model_quant = converter.convert() What does (1) and (100) in this line mean? [for input_value in tf.data.Dataset.from_tensor_slices(train_images).batch(1).take(100):]

comments.comment: Hi LinYouWei, 1 is the batch size and 100 is the number of samples. Normally TFLite infer sample by sample (i.e. batch_size = 1) and representative dataset takes in a few samples in order to have a good calibration on per layer min / max value. Feel free to refer to this doc on the usage of tf.data.Dataset <denchmark-link:https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data>https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/data</denchmark-link>
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you.
